data.title: Sun Belt Plays Opens at Home Against Little Rock and Arkansas State
data.meta_description: SAN MARCOS, Texas – Texas State (7-4) opens its seventh season of Sun Belt Conference play this weekend at home as it hosts Little Rock and Arkansas State for a
data.text:
Scott M Foley

Women's Basketball 1/1/2020 2:11:00 PM

Sun Belt Plays Opens at Home Against Little Rock and Arkansas State

SAN MARCOS, Texas – Texas State (7-4) opens its seventh season of Sun Belt Conference play this weekend at home as it hosts Little Rock and Arkansas State for a pair of games. The Trojans serve as the league lidlifter at 7 p.m. on Thursday, Jan. 2. The Red Wolves and Bobcats will battle at 2 p.m. on Saturday, Jan. 4. Brant Freeman and Suzanne Fox will have the call on ESPN+ and Clint Shields has the radio play-by-play call on 89.9 KTSW and txstatebobcats.com for both games.

#BobcatBits

TXST has never lost a Sun Belt Conference opener and is 6-0 since joining the league in 2013-14. This is the first year the Bobcats have opened conference play at home since 2016-17 when it downed Coastal Carolina, 83-62.

The Bobcats are a perfect 6-0 inside Strahan Arena this year and finished non-conference play undefeated at home for the first time since 2015-16. TXST is averaging 67.3 points per game at home, 5.1 points better than its overall season average. The Bobcats closed out the decade at home with a win over Alcorn State and went 89-57 in San Marcos from 2010-19.

Head coach Zenarae Antoine is in her ninth season and has amassed 132 wins. She is the fourth head coach in program history to reach the benchmark and is six wins from tying Linda Sharp (1989-97) for third-most victories in school history.

The Bobcats average 20.6 turnovers forced per game which is 36th in the NCAA and ranks second in the Sun Belt. Texas State has excelled in winning the turnover battle this year and lead the Sun Belt with a +4.73 turnover margin.

In its last game against Alcorn State, Texas State grabbed 53 rebounds, its most in the last nine seasons.

Texas State is 6-0 this year when limiting its opposition to 60 or fewer points. Texas State held four non-conference opponents under 50 points for the first time since it held five under the mark in 2006-07.

The Bobcats recently wrapped up non-conference play this year and finished the last five seasons with a 20-5 mark at home against non-league foes.

Taylor Enjoying Hot Sophomore Start

Sophomore guard Kennedy Taylor's 4.9 assists per game and 54 total assists lead the Sun Belt Conference. She ranks 48th nationally in the statistic and tied her season-high with eight dimes against Alcorn State. The point guard also ranks third in the conference with a 1.50 assist turnover ratio.

Taylor has scored in double figures in five of the last six games and is second on the team averaging 10.2 points per game. She posted a career-best 22 points in the Dec. 4 overtime win over I-35 Rival UTSA.

Taylor flirted with a double-double in her last contest against Alcorn State and dropped 16 points, tied her season-high with eight assists and collected a career-best six rebounds. The point guard also set a career-high by draining seven free throws.

The Dallas, Texas native has been one of the most durable players in the Sun Belt this year and is fourth among conference leaders in minutes played per game (33.5).

Holle Twins Lead the Bobcats in Senior Seasons

Twin sister senior guards Brooke and Bailey Holley both place in the top four in SBC steal totals. Brooke is second in steals per game (2.5) and total steals (27) while Bailey is tied for fourth in steals per game (2.1) and tied for third in total steals (23). Brooke has registered a steal in every game this year and has notched two five steal contests against UTSA and Morgan State.

Senior guard Brooke Holle is attempting to become the 19th player in Texas State women's basketball history to accumulate 1,000 career points. Holle has scored 815 points during her four seasons for the Maroon and Gold and has netted 300-plus points in each of the last two complete seasons.

She has made 111-of-349 (31.8 percent) of her three-point attempts during her career and needs just six triples to crack the top-10 list for career made three-pointers at Texas State. Toshua Leavitt (2015-19) is the Sun Belt Conference and Texas State career leader with 363 triples.

Brooke is the team's active career leader in points (815), rebounds (453), assists (144) and steals (119) She leads the team in rebounding this year (6.1 rpg) and is third in scoring (9.8 ppg).

Over her last six games Holle has gone 21-for-26 at the free throw stripe.

Brooke Holle garnered Sun Belt Player of the Week honors for the first time in her career (Dec. 16).

Bailey Holle has excelled in her sixth-player role this year and is averaging 25 minutes per game off the bench. She dropped a season-high 11 points on the road at Morgan State while tying a career-high with three triples.

Bailey completed her undergraduate degree in business administration at the conclusion of the fall semester. She was unable to attend the ceremony due to the Bobcats road game at Dartmouth on Dec. 15 but will receive her diploma in the spring. The Austin, Texas native will wear a Sun Belt Graduate patch on her jersey the remainder of the season and begin postgraduate work to pursue a master's in business administration in the fall semester.

Bobcat Player Notes

Junior guard Avionne Alexander set a career-high with seven assists at Morgan State. She is the first Bobcat to post at least five assists and not record a turnover this year.

Sophomore forward Da'Nasia Hood leads the team in scoring averaging 11.1 points per game and has scored at least 10 points in five of the last six games. She posted a career-best 14 rebounds in the last game against Alcorn State.

Scouting Little Rock

The Trojans are the two-time defending Sun Belt Conference Tournament champions and were picked to win the league in the preseason coaches' poll but have opened the year 2-9 against a very challenging slate. Little Rock has played the 21st toughest schedule in the nation and lost its last two contests against nationally ranked foes in #20 Arkansas (86-53) and #15 Mississippi State (89-50).

Both wins this season came at home against I-40 Showdown rival Central Arkansas (63-48) and Tulsa (63-51).

Reigning Sun Belt Conference Tournament MVP, senior guard Kyra Collier, leads the club and ranks second in the Sun Belt in scoring (15.9 ppg) while playing a conference-best 38.4 minutes per game.

Little Rock is 12th in the Sun Belt in scoring (52.0 ppg) and have been held at 40 or fewer points three times.

Redshirt sophomore forward Krystan Vornes leads the team in rebounding (6.1 rpg).

Joe Foley is the Dean of Sun Belt Conference head coaches and is currently in his 17th season guiding the program. He has been a head coach for 33 seasons in the NCAA and has an all-time record of 791-264 and 335-183 at Little Rock.

Scouting Arkansas State

The Red Wolves check into the weekend with a 3-8 record and will play at UTA on Thursday evening before taking on Texas State on Saturday. Arkansas State was picked to finish 10th in the Sun Belt Conference in the preseason coaches' poll. Two of its three wins came against Division I competition in San Diego State (71-62) and Arkansas-Pine Bluff (81-60).

Arkansas State has lost its last three games all on the road against Memphis (78-50), #7 Baylor (111-43) and Louisiana Tech (67-54).

Arkansas State is one of the better three-point shooting teams in the Sun Belt and rank third in the league in three-point field goals made per game (5.7) and fourth in three-point field goal percentage (28.5).

Preseason All-Sun Belt Conference Third Team selection, junior forward Peyton Martin, leads the team in scoring (13.6 ppg). Junior guard Morgan Wallace has pulled down a team-best 7.9 rebounds per game.

Matt Daniel is in his first year as head coach at Arkansas State. He made prior head coaching stops at Marshall and Central Arkansas.

Series History

vs. Little Rock - The Trojans lead the all-time series, 11-6, and lead conference-only meetings, 9-4. The two squads split last year's series with each team winning on its home floor. Texas State took the last meeting, 50-48, on Feb. 16, 2019. This season's league lidlifter marks the second time the two have met to open conference action. Texas State defeated the Trojans 42-35 in 2013-14 as part of the first ever SBC league game for the Bobcats.

vs. Arkansas State – The Red Wolves have a slight 6-5 edge in the neck-and-neck series, but the Bobcats have won the last four meetings. Texas State won at home on Feb. 14 68-54 and were led by Brooke Holle's 21 points.

Up Next

Texas State travels to take on Coastal Carolina and Appalachian State in the second week of conference action. Tip is set for 5 p.m. CST on Thursday, Jan. 9 against CCU and 1 p.m. CST on Saturday, Jan. 11 against App State.

Follow the Bobcats

Be sure to follow Texas State on Twitter and Instagram for news and in-game updates about the squad.
